qas.question: From what language is Portuguese derived?
By what group of people is Portuguese derived?

answers.text: Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula

qas.question: Between what years did Portugal establish a colonial and commercial empire?
In how many continents is Portuguese spoken as a native language?
What country has the largest number of native Portuguese speakers?

context: The Portuguese language is derived from the <a0_0>Latin<a0_0/> spoken by the romanized <a1_0>Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula<a1_0/> around 2000 years ago—particularly the Celts, Tartessians, Lusitanians and Iberians. In the 15th and 16th centuries, the language spread worldwide as Portugal established a colonial and commercial empire between <a2_0>1415 and 1999<a2_0/>. Portuguese is now spoken as a native language in <a3_0>five<a3_0/> different continents, with <a4_0>Brazil<a4_0/> accounting for the largest number of native Portuguese speakers of any country (200 million speakers in 2012).
